title: Virchow Node -- Definition/Introduction
content: Virchow's node, a left supraclavicular lymph node, was first described by German pathologist Rudolf Ludwig Karl Virchow (1821-1901) in 1848 as a sign of metastatic malignancy mainly from gastric cancer. [1] The term "Troisier sign" describes an enlarged palpable hard left supraclavicular node following Charles-Emile Troisier's work, which is now sometimes used interchangeably with Virchow's node. [2]

title: Virchow Node -- Definition/Introduction
content: Several studies have established its clinical significance by demonstrating its association with various malignancies, including gastrointestinal, pulmonary adenocarcinoma, prostate cancer, and lymphoma, among others. [1] [3] [4] [5] [6] Considering its role in lymphatic drainage, researchers have theorized that its involvement in malignancies could be due to tumor embolization along the thoracic duct. [1] [2] Although there have been just a few studies on its anatomic description, they have helped understand the possible complications Virchow's node's mass effect can cause, including thoracic outlet syndrome, horner's syndrome, and unilateral phrenic neuropathy. [1] [7] [8]

title: Virchow Node -- Issues of Concern
content: Virchow's node, a left supraclavicular lymph node, was first described by German pathologist Rudolf Ludwig Karl Virchow (1821-1901) in 1848 as a sign of metastatic malignancy mainly from gastric cancer. [1] Subsequently, in 1889, French pathologist Charles-Emile Troisier (1844-1919) reported findings of enlarged palpable hard left supraclavicular lymph nodes linked to not just metastatic spread of gastric cancer, but also other malignancies including GI, kidneys, testes, ovaries, and certain infections (eg, tuberculosis, syphilis). [2] The term " Troisier sign" was coined and is now sometimes used interchangeably with Virchow's node.

title: Virchow Node -- Issues of Concern
content: Following Virchow's and Troisier's work, researchers have conducted a few studies on the anatomic description of Virchow's node. One of those studies by MitZutani et al described the Virchow's node and its anatomic variations on 5  subjects with thoracic end nodes, with 2 adhered to the carotid sheath and the other three anterior to the anterior scalene muscle. [9] Another was by Matthew J Zdilla et al using a cadaver with pulmonary adenocarcinoma with metastasis to the Virchow's node. [5] In this study, they found Virchow's node to be located in the lesser supraclavicular fossa deep to the platysma and clavicular head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, superolateral to the venous angle, and anterior to the anterior scalene muscle (forms the anterior border of the scalene triangle through which the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels run), phrenic nerve, and transverse cervical artery.

title: Virchow Node -- Issues of Concern
content: Virchow's node is a lymph node and part of the lymphatic system. It is the thoracic duct end node. It receives afferent lymphatic drainage from the left head, neck, chest, abdomen, pelvis, and bilateral lower extremities, which eventually drains into the jugulo-subclavian venous junction via the thoracic duct. [10]

title: Virchow Node -- Clinical Significance
content: Numerous studies have shown Virchow's node to be clinically significant, especially concerning malignancies. Due to its lymphatic function, the Virchow's node is a potential seeding site for not only gastrointestinal malignancies but also pulmonary adenocarcinoma, prostate cancer, lymphoma, and ovarian cancer, among others. [1] [3] [5] [6] [5] [3] [11] [12] [13] [14] [15] Some think this lymphadenopathy's mechanism in malignancy is due to tumor embolization from the primary sites through the thoracic duct, which eventually involves the Virchow's node, where some cancer cells become trapped with resultant enlargement. Virchow's node enlargement or Troisier sign also has links to infections like tuberculosis, a theory earlier postulated in Troisier's studies. [16]

title: Virchow Node -- Clinical Significance
content: Considering its anatomy, researchers have theorized that Virchow's node results in certain complications secondary to mass effect. [5] One of these is a neurogenic and vascular thoracic outlet syndrome, as it lies on the anterior scalene muscle underneath, which contacts the brachial plexus and subclavian vessel and becomes compressed secondary to its enlargement. [17] Virchow's node can also result in unilateral phrenic neuropathy-ipsilateral diaphragmatic weakness but is mostly asymptomatic, as the left phrenic nerve runs posterior to it. Horner syndrome would be another possible complication due to the proximity of Virchow's node to the cervical sympathetic chain. [8] Virchow's node is an important clinical finding associated with metastatic malignancy, certain infections, and even a potential cause of neurovascular pathologies, and hence, it should merit consideration in clinical practice.

title: Virchow Node -- Nursing, Allied Health, and Interprofessional Team Interventions
content: Due to the clinical significance of Virchow's node, all healthcare team members with clinical responsibilities should familiarize themselves with identifying it in patients so they can report it to the appropriate clinicians for further evaluation.
